bestBHT.bht: When Apollos was inclined to go to Achaia, the believers in Ephesus wrote a sincere letter of recommendation to the disciples in Corinth to receive him. Apollos had greatly helped and contributed to the advantage of the believers, not by his own eloquence or deep learning, but through the grace of God. It is important to note that faith is a production of God's grace in the heart, which is why Apollos was able to exhort and urge the believers through the grace that had been imparted to him.

Henry Alford: The for, which follows, should be noticed. His coming was a valuable assistance to the Christians against the Jews, in the controversies which had doubtless been going on since Paul’s departure."
Those who had believed through grace.
The rendering in the text is much more probable,—those who had believed through grace.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: And when he was disposed to pass into Achaia, there to proclaim that Gospel which he now more fully comprehended.
A beautiful specimen of 'letters of recommendation'... by which, as well as by interchange of deputations, &c., the early churches maintained active Christian fellowship with each other.

One of those incidental expressions which show that faith's being a production of God's grace in the heart was so current and recognized a truth that it was taken for granted, as a necessary consequence of the general system of grace.
Albert Barnes: Many of the Greeks at Corinth were greatly captivated with his winning eloquence.
But in all this he retained the confidence and love of Paul.
It was thus shown that Paul was superior to envy, and that great success by one minister need not excite the envy, or alienate the confidence and good will of another.
Marvin Vincent: Exhorting. Originally, to turn forward, as in flight. Hence, to impel or urge."
Helped. The radical sense of the word is to throw together: hence, to contribute; to help; to be useful to.
Through grace. Grace has the article, the special grace of God imparted.
John Calvin: This is holy commendation indeed, when we study to extol every good man with our testimony and consent, [suffrage,] lest the gifts of the Holy Ghost, which he hath given to every man for the edifying of the Church, lie buried.
I take it that they were helped both ways; that having a skillful and practiced captain, they got the victory in the conflict.
Apollos, in imparting that grace which he had received with the brethren, did help them. So that, through grace, shall import as much as according to the measure of the grace received.
Philip Schaff: He felt that there was a great work for him to do.

They guaranteed at once his soundness in the faith and his personal character, and served to give a reality to the belief in the 'communion of saints' as the necessary sequel to the recognition of a Catholic or universal Church.

The real assistance, after all, which this eloquent and skilled man afforded to the believers of Corinth, was owing neither to his winning eloquence nor deep learning, but to the grace of God, to the Divine influence.
Archibald T. Robertson: Since Apollos wanted (βουλομενου αυτου, genitive absolute) to go into Achaia, the brethren (including others besides Priscilla and Aquila) wrote (εγραψαν) a letter of introduction to the disciples in Corinth to receive him (αποδεξασθα αυτον), a nice letter of recommendation and a sincere one also.
Priscilla and Aquila were well known in Corinth and their approval would carry weight. But they did not urge Apollos to stay longer in Ephesus.

Through grace (δια της χαριτος). This makes sense if taken with 'believed,' as Hackett does (cf. Acts 13:48; Acts 16:14) or with 'helped' (1 Corinthians 3:10; 1 Corinthians 15:10; 2 Corinthians 1:12). Both are true as the references show.
John Gill: What disposed him to go thither, after he had received a greater degree of light and knowledge, was no doubt that he might communicate it, to the good of others, to which he was moved by the Holy Ghost.
Apollos, through the gifts of grace bestowed on him, or by the assistance of the grace of God, or both, greatly helped and contributed much to the advantage of the believers in those parts.

Faith is not of nature, nor the produce of man's free will, but is the gift of God's grace; it is a fruit of electing grace, an instance of distinguishing grace, it is owing to efficacious grace, and comes along with effectual calling grace, through the word preached, the means of grace; and is supported and maintained by the grace of God.
John Wesley: It is through grace only that any gift of any one is profitable to another.
Apollos did not plant, but water. This was the peculiar gift which he had received.
He was better able to convince the Jews, than to convert the heathens.

bhtAttempts.bht: When Apollos was inclined to go to Achaia, the believers in Ephesus wrote a sincere letter of recommendation to the disciples in Corinth to receive him. Apollos had greatly helped and contributed to the advantage of the believers, not by his own eloquence or deep learning, but through the grace of God. It is important to note that faith is a production of God's grace in the heart, which is why Apollos was able to exhort and urge the believers through the grace that had been imparted to him.

When Apollos desired to go to Achaia, the believers in Ephesus sent a letter of recommendation to the disciples in Corinth to receive him. Apollos greatly assisted and contributed to the believers, not through his own eloquence or learning, but through the grace of God. This highlights the fact that faith is a product of God's grace in the heart, enabling Apollos to exhort and urge the believers with the grace that had been given to him.

When Apollos intended to go to Achaia, the believers in Ephesus wrote a letter of recommendation to the disciples in Corinth. Apollos greatly contributed and helped the believers through the grace of God, not relying on his own eloquence or learning. This underscores the truth that faith is a manifestation of God's grace in the heart, allowing Apollos to exhort and urge the believers with the grace given to him.

When Apollos desired to go to Achaia, the believers in Ephesus wrote a letter of recommendation to the disciples in Corinth regarding Apollos, as they recognized his contribution and assistance to the believers. Apollos was able to help and contribute through the grace of God, not his own eloquence or learning. This highlights that faith is a product of God's grace in the heart, allowing Apollos to exhort and urge the believers with the grace given to him.

When Apollos wanted to go to Achaia, the believers in Ephesus wrote a letter of recommendation to the disciples in Corinth to receive him. Apollos greatly helped and contributed to the advantage of the believers in those parts through the gifts of grace bestowed on him and the assistance of the grace of God. This highlights that faith is not a production of man's free will, but a gift of God's grace, and that it is through grace that any gift of one person is profitable to another.
